articles.headline: In Effort to Defeat ISIS, U.S. and Iran Impede One Another
articles.snippet: Civilians have been trapped in Falluja, where the Islamic State is under siege, and Shiite militias have stoked tensions elsewhere in Anbar Province.
articles.abstract: Civilians have been trapped in Falluja, where the Islamic State is under siege, and Shiite militias have stoked tensions elsewhere in Anbar Province.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi forces, backed by American airstrikes and advised by American officers, have been making strides in Anbar Province, slowly taking back territory from the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Regulators Approve Charter Communications Deal for Time Warner Cable
articles.snippet: The approvals create a broadband and cable television juggernaut at a time when consumers rely on the Internet as a utility.
articles.abstract: The approvals create a broadband and cable television juggernaut at a time when consumers rely on the Internet as a utility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Monday moved to approve Charter Communications’ $65.5 billion acquisitions of Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, enabling the creation of a new cable giant as the industry focuses more on broadband as traditional TV declines.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Ted Cruz-John Kasich Alliance Against Donald Trump Quickly Weakens
articles.snippet: An agreement between the Republican candidates Ted Cruz and John Kasich, who agreed to cede states to each other, shows signs of fraying.
articles.abstract: An agreement between the Republican candidates Ted Cruz and John Kasich, who agreed to cede states to each other, shows signs of fraying.
articles.lead_paragraph: The temporary alliance between Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, formed to deny Donald J. Trump the Republican presidential nomination, was already fraying almost to the point of irrelevance on Monday, only hours after it was announced to great fanfare.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Matt Flegenheimer and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Advisers to F.D.A. Vote Against Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Drug
articles.snippet: The staff of the F.D.A. said a clinical trial for the drug was too small, but advocates said the drug prolonged patients’ ability to walk.
articles.abstract: The staff of the F.D.A. said a clinical trial for the drug was too small, but advocates said the drug prolonged patients’ ability to walk.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a confrontation between the hopes of desperate patients and clinical trial data, advisers to the Food and Drug Administration voted on Monday not to recommend approval of what would become the first drug for Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

articles.headline: China Curbs Plans for More Coal-Fired Power Plants
articles.snippet: The country, the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases, halted plans for new coal-fired plants and postponed building of some already approved.
articles.abstract: The country, the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases, halted plans for new coal-fired plants and postponed building of some already approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Coal-fired power plants have propelled much of China’s economic rise for decades, helping make the nation the world’s biggest emitter of greenhouse gases. Even with economic growth slackening, and other energy sources taking hold, new coal plants have been added.

articles.headline: Tribune Plays Coy as Gannett Makes a Bid
articles.snippet: Tribune’s nonexecutive chairman, Michael Ferro, may have his own reasons for stalling for more time.
articles.abstract: Tribune’s nonexecutive chairman, Michael Ferro, may have his own reasons for stalling for more time.
articles.lead_paragraph: A recent history of mistakes, slip-ups and management blunders is woven into the fabric of Tribune Publishing, the struggling publisher of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.

articles.headline: For Bill Gross, Besting Pimco Is the Best Revenge
articles.snippet: While buoyed by professional triumphs since leaving the mutual fund giant, William Gross has not put his time there and the way it ended behind him.
articles.abstract: While buoyed by professional triumphs since leaving the mutual fund giant, William Gross has not put his time there and the way it ended behind him.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Sitting in the conference room of his empty office suite, with its floor-to-ceiling wall of windows, William H. Gross cannot help noticing the sleek office tower that the bond giant Pimco moved into in early 2014.

articles.headline: Federal Judge Upholds North Carolina Voter Rules
articles.snippet: The state demonstrated a legitimate interest in requiring voters to provide certain credentials before casting their ballots, he ruled.
articles.abstract: The state demonstrated a legitimate interest in requiring voters to provide certain credentials before casting their ballots, he ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — A federal judge on Monday upheld sweeping Republican-backed changes to election rules, including a voter identification provision, that civil rights groups say unfairly targeted African-Americans and other minorities. The ruling could have serious political repercussions in a state that is closely contested in presidential elections.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Where Jobs Are Squeezed by Chinese Trade, Voters Seek Extremes
articles.snippet: Research suggests that globalization and related job losses since the turn of the century have contributed heavily to the nation’s bitter political divide.
articles.abstract: Research suggests that globalization and related job losses since the turn of the century have contributed heavily to the nation’s bitter political divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: COURTLAND, Ala. — In this forlorn Southern town whose once-humming factories were battered in recent years by a flood of Asian imports, Rhonda Hughes, 43, is a fervent supporter of Donald Trump. Her 72-year old mother is equally passionate about Senator Bernie Sanders.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Quoctrung Bui

articles.headline: An Heir Who’s Ready to Take the Reins at New York Magazine
articles.snippet: Two years after the editor Adam Moss told Pamela Wasserstein she ought to run the magazine bought by her father in 2004, she’s becoming chief of its parent company.
articles.abstract: Two years after the editor Adam Moss told Pamela Wasserstein she ought to run the magazine bought by her father in 2004, she’s becoming chief of its parent company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Moss, the editor in chief of New York magazine, was having dinner at Sant Ambroeus, an upscale restaurant in the West Village, with Pamela Wasserstein and her two brothers when she mentioned that she was ready for a career change.

articles.headline: At Chobani, Now It’s Not Just the Yogurt That’s Rich
articles.snippet: The company surprised its 2,000 full-time workers with shares in the company that could make some of them millionaires.
articles.abstract: The company surprised its 2,000 full-time workers with shares in the company that could make some of them millionaires.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BERLIN, N.Y. — The 2,000 full-time employees of the yogurt company Chobani were handed quite the surprise on Tuesday: an ownership stake that could make some of them millionaires.

articles.headline: He Disavowed Radical Islam. Was He Lying?
articles.snippet: The case of seven men who went to Syria and returned home reflects a quandary for France and the rest of the Continent after the attacks in Paris and Brussels.
articles.abstract: The case of seven men who went to Syria and returned home reflects a quandary for France and the rest of the Continent after the attacks in Paris and Brussels.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ten young Muslim men, bored by a mundane life in France and haunted by a “feeling of uselessness,” as one put it, were seduced by a leading Islamic State recruiter in Europe in 2013. Within months, they were in Syria under the watchful eyes of hooded, Kalashnikov-wielding militants, doing push-ups, fiddling with weapons and imbibing the ideology.

articles.headline: The Mirage of a Return to Manufacturing Greatness
articles.snippet: As the candidates for president grapple with a vanishing manufacturing base, their solutions ignore the reality of an irrevocable change in the global economy.
articles.abstract: As the candidates for president grapple with a vanishing manufacturing base, their solutions ignore the reality of an irrevocable change in the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, harvesting California’s 2.2 million tons of tomatoes for ketchup required as many as 45,000 workers. In the 1960s, though, scientists and engineers at the University of California, Davis, developed an oblong tomato that lent itself to being machine-picked and an efficient mechanical harvester to do the job in one pass through a field.
